summary: new taxonomy divides the Coronavirinae subfamily into four genera. only the alpha and beta species infect humans [1]. HCoV-NL63 is the major etiological factor of croup in young children. the HCoV-NL63 protein encodes the viral replicative machinery within the 5’ part and the structural proteins within the 3’ part. the protein forms a ribonucleoprotein together with genomic RNA. it is then inserted into a lipid envelope carrying other structural proteins responsible for membrane curvature formation, vesicle scission, and interaction with cellular receptors. NL63-N shares characteristics with homologous proteins encoded by other coronaviruses. it forms oligomers via its C-terminal domain (CTD) and binds nucleic acids via its N-terminal domain (NTD) fetal bovine serum (FBS; PCR product was cloned into the pmaxFP-Green-N plasmid (Lonza, Switzerland) using restriction sites. plasmids for prokaryotic expression of the NL63-N protein were prepared using pmaxFP-Green-N as a template. the element encoding 6 His tag was introduced at the N-terminus of the gene. three plasmids for prokaryotic expression were generated. transfection of eukaryotic cells Plasmid pmaxFP-Green-N/NL63-N or control plasmids were transfected. in vitro transcription was carried out using mMessage mMachine SP6 kit. RNA was polyadenylated using poly(A) Tailing Kit. transfected into cells using transIT-mRNA Transfection Kit (Mirus, USA) g/ml propidium iodide and 10 g/ml RNase A were visualized with monoclonal antibody specific to NL63-N (Ingenasa, Spain) and secondary Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-mouse antibody (Life Technologies, Poland) all experiments were conducted independently at least three times. fluorescent images were acquired with leica TCS SP5 II confocal microscope (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Germany) images were pre-processed using Leica Application Suite Advanced Fluorescence LAS AF v. 2.2.1 (Leica Microsystems GmbH) and further deconvolved with Huygens Essential package ver. 4.4 (Scientific Volume Imaging B.V., the Netherlands) 2og3 P59595 Human SARS CoV Nucleocapsid NTD [51] 2ca1 P69596 Avian IBV (strain Beaudette) Nucleocapsid CTD [56] 2ge7 P32923 Avian IBV (strain Grey) Nucleocapsid CTD [56] 2cjr P59595 Human SARS CoV Nucleocapsid CTD [81] 2jw8 P mass spectrometry Samples were prepared by dialysis into 50 mM NH4HCO3, pH 7.8. measurements were performed using the MicroTOF-QII mass spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) the obtained MS spectra were analyzed using Data Analysis 4.0 software (Bruker, Germany) 7.8 was recorded relative to pure buffer at a scan rate of 1 K/min. the enthalpy was defined as the temperature corresponding to the peak maximum. the ration = H(Tm)/HvH should be equal to unity. samples were separated on agarose gels and signal from nucleic acids was visualized with ethidium bromide staining. all experiments were conducted independently at least three times. NL63-N fragment encompassing its CTD was chosen exclusively on the basis of sequence alignment and structural analysis. fragment 221–340 contains full, structurally stable CTD. the sequences and structures of N proteins used in above analysis are listed in S1 File. NL63-N underwent irreversible denaturation and showed a broad transition curve. the denaturation temperature was estimated at 45.7°C, with an enthalpy change of approximately 80 kcal/mol. however, due to low signal to noise ratio the baseline was variable. the coronaviral nucleocapsid forms a protective scaffold around the viral RNA [52–54] the N protein forms oligomers via specific interactions between different regions within the protein. similar results were obtained for the CTD but not NTD, suggesting that CTD harbors the sites responsible for N protein dimerization. NTD complexes were stabilized by means of protein crosslinking and analyzed with SDS-PAGE electrophoresis (Coomassie brilliant blue staining) the CTD was analyzed with size exclusion chromatography; two peaks visible on the chromatogram (a and b) represent dimeric and monomeric forms of the CTD respectively. subcellular localization of the N protein Coronaviral N proteins localize to the cytoplasm, where they are involved in virus replication and assembly. however, the N proteins of almost all coronaviruses localize to the nucleus or to micronuclei [58–61] plasm may be attributed to vast overexpression of the protein. similar patterns were previously seen for other coronaviruses. fected LLC-MK2 and 293T cells with RNA encoding NL63-N. analysis was performed using LLC-MK2 cells (A.) and 293T cells (B.). no significant difference in cell cycle progression in NL63-N-expressing and non-expressing cells. NL63-N fragment encompassing its CTD was chosen exclusively on the basis of sequence alignment and structural analysis. fragment 221–340 contains full, structurally stable CTD. the sequences and structures of N proteins used in above analysis are listed in S1 File. NL63-N underwent irreversible denaturation and showed a broad transition curve. the denaturation temperature was estimated at 45.7°C, with an enthalpy change of approximately 80 kcal/mol. but due to low signal to noise ratio the resulting baseline was variable. TD H kcal/mol 81.05 143.6 104.4 Tt (°C) 45.7 55.7 45.0 S kcal/K*mol - 0.44 - Oligomerization of the N protein is mediated by the CTD The coronaviral nucleocapsid forms a protective scaffold around the viral RNA. similar results were obtained for the CTD but not NTD. analyzed with SDS-PAGE electrophoresis (Coomassie brilliant blue staining) the CTD was analyzed with size exclusion chromatography. two peaks visible on the chromatogram represent dimeric and monomeric forms of the CTD respectively. micrographs were prepared using scanning electron microscope JSM-5410. subcellular localization of the N protein Coronaviral N proteins localize to the cytoplasm. however, the N proteins of almost all coronaviruses localize to the nucleus or to micronuclei. cells infected with HCoV-NL63 did not result in formation of such structures. similar patterns were previously seen for other coronaviruses. NL63-N is a basic protein comprising of 377 aa. only cells expressing NL63-N were used for subsequent analyses. no significant difference in cell cycle progression in NL63-N-expressing cells. in general, H represents the energy amount of non-covalent bonds occurring within native protein. this is consistent with our finding that the N protein rapidly degrades in aqueous solutions. Obtained results are consistent with previous reports [55,66,67]. however, the CTD was surprisingly stable. the existence of the exotherm on the downhill part of endotherm DSC peak is the obvious evidence for the presence of association-aggregation processes. lower stability of NTD and the complete N protein could be attributed to the distinct structural flexibility of these proteins. in turn, higher flexibility allows NTD to bind nucleic acids which has obvious biological relevance for NTD and complete N protein function. oligomerization of the 229E-N protein is most likely also mediated by the CTD. NL63-N strongly binds nucleic acids during formation of the ribonucleocapsid. this interaction may be important for stabilizing and shaping the ribonucleocapsid. we tested a fully differentiated human airway epithelium cultures. the NL63-N protein does not localize to the nucleus. it is possible that the lack of nuclear staining may be due to poor antibody staining. polypeptide sequence encompassing the N-terminal domain of N protein from HCoV-NL63 was based on the sequence alignment with homologous N proteins together with the structural comparative analysis. the sequence of HCoV-NL63 N protein predicted to constitute the structurally stable N-terminal domain is colored blue. sequences of N proteins were aligned: Q6Q1R8, HCoV NL63; P69596, avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV, strain Beaudette), sequence referring to the 2ca1 crystal structure; P32923, IBV (strain Gray), sequence referring to the 2ge7 crystal structure; P59595, human SARS coronavirus. sequence of HCoV-NL63 N protein predicted to constitute the structurally stable C- analysis was carried on with confocal microscopy using leica TCS SP5 II confocal microscope. Virions were labelled with antibodies specific to the N-NL63 protein (green); DNA was stained with DAPI (blue). analysis was carried on with confocal microscopy using leica TCS SP5 II confocal microscope.
